dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: So this idea of having two jobs, job number one and job number two, it's pretty wild.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: So this idea of having two jobs, job number one and job number two, it's pretty wild.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: Yeah, and job number one is all about being disruptive and self-centered, right? Like, you're constantly looking for ways to add value but in a way that actually makes you less useful to others.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Yeah, and job number one is all about being disruptive and self-centered, right? Like, you're constantly looking for ways to add value but in a way that actually makes you less useful to others.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Job no. 1 forces you to value relationships and be other-centered. Instead of thinking first about your own self-interest, you think first about the interests of others: clients, peers, and even your boss.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: Exactly. It's here, like with clients, you become someone who takes advantage of their interests instead of just selling them what they need. That's a huge shift in mindset.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Exactly. It's here, like with clients, you become someone who takes advantage of their interests instead of just selling them what they need. That's a huge shift in mindset.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: For example, with clients, you become a person who serves their interests, instead of a pushy, aggressive type who is always selling something they don't need.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: And then there's job number two, the one that actually pays your bills, but according to this, it's where you end up undermining the goals of the people who hired you.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: And then there's job number two, the one that actually pays your bills, but according to this, it's where you end up undermining the goals of the people who hired you.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Job no. 2 is how you get paid, feed your family, and pursue the agenda of the people who hired you.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: Right, like instead of organizing an important meeting, you're spending all morning gossiping about a lost cat. It's almost like self-sabotage disguised as being helpful.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Right, like instead of organizing an important meeting, you're spending all morning gossiping about a lost cat. It's almost like self-sabotage disguised as being helpful.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Instead of organizing that critical meeting, they end up spending all morning calling neighbors to see if anyone spotted the lost cat that may - or may not - have been wandering on the edge of their neighborhood.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: But the core insight is that these two jobs compete with each other. Job number one makes you worse at job number two.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: But the core insight is that these two jobs compete with each other. Job number one makes you worse at job number two.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Job no. 1 does not compete with job no. 2. Job no. 1 makes you much better at job no. 2.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: And it destroys relationships, isolates you… it's kind of scary how that plays out in real life.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: And it destroys relationships, isolates you... it's kind of scary how that plays out in real life.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: It builds stronger relationships. It connects you more strongly to others.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: I mean, Bruce Kasanoff really pushes this idea that you have to take both jobs seriously, invest equal energy in each.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: I mean, Bruce Kasanoff really pushes this idea that you have to take both jobs seriously, invest equal energy in each.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Take both jobs seriously. Invest equal energy in each.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: Even though job number one doesn't pay you in cash, it pays in other rewards—but some of those actions can deplete your soul, he says.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Even though job number one doesn't pay you in cash, it pays in other rewards-but some of those actions can deplete your soul, he says.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Not every reward is financial. Some actions feed your soul, enrich your community, and model the sort of behaviors you want your peers, friends, and family members to emulate.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: Yeah, and he even suggests making to-do lists for both jobs and analyzing your failures in each. That's intense.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Yeah, and he even suggests making to-do lists for both jobs and analyzing your failures in each. That's intense.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: At the end of each week, month, and year analyze your performance and achievements in both positions.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: It feels counterintuitive though, right? Like, why would you actively pursue something that makes you worse at your actual job?
dialogue_turns.tts_text: It feels counterintuitive though, right? Like, why would you actively pursue something that makes you worse at your actual job?

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: I think the point is to recognize that tension and maybe find a balance, or at least be aware of how one affects the other.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: I think the point is to recognize that tension and maybe find a balance, or at least be aware of how one affects the other.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: For sure. It's not about choosing one over the other but acknowledging that both exist and impact your career satisfaction.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: For sure. It's not about choosing one over the other but acknowledging that both exist and impact your career satisfaction.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: Makes you rethink what it means to be "too smart" for your job—maybe it's not about intelligence but about misaligned priorities.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Makes you rethink what it means to be too smart for your job-maybe it's not about intelligence but about misaligned priorities.

artist_script:
Forty percent of professionals feel they're too smart for their jobs—what's the real cost of that mismatch?
HostA: So this idea of having two jobs, job number one and job number two, it’s pretty wild.
HostB: Yeah, and job number one is all about being disruptive and self-centered, right? Like, you’re constantly looking for ways to add value but in a way that actually makes you less useful to others.
HostA: Exactly. It’s here, like with clients, you become someone who takes advantage of their interests instead of just selling them what they need. That’s a huge shift in mindset.
HostB: And then there’s job number two, the one that actually pays your bills, but according to this, it’s where you end up undermining the goals of the people who hired you.
HostA: Right, like instead of organizing an important meeting, you’re spending all morning gossiping about a lost cat. It’s almost like self-sabotage disguised as being helpful.
HostB: But the core insight is that these two jobs compete with each other. Job number one makes you worse at job number two.
HostA: And it destroys relationships, isolates you… it’s kind of scary how that plays out in real life.
HostB: I mean, Bruce Kasanoff really pushes this idea that you have to take both jobs seriously, invest equal energy in each.
HostA: Even though job number one doesn’t pay you in cash, it pays in other rewards—but some of those actions can deplete your soul, he says.
HostB: Yeah, and he even suggests making to-do lists for both jobs and analyzing your failures in each. That’s intense.
HostA: It feels counterintuitive though, right? Like, why would you actively pursue something that makes you worse at your actual job?
HostB: I think the point is to recognize that tension and maybe find a balance, or at least be aware of how one affects the other.
HostA: For sure. It’s not about choosing one over the other but acknowledging that both exist and impact your career satisfaction.
HostB: Makes you rethink what it means to be "too smart" for your job—maybe it’s not about intelligence but about misaligned priorities.
